text: Yeah, there is a thin, really, really thin line between love and hate when it comes to writing haha. The thing is that today it's harder than ever to sit and write uninterruptedly for a longer time, without checking Twitter threads, cat memes, TikTok videos or Facebook groups. Maybe that's where my (and not only mine) problem lies. That's why I ordered "Deep work" by Cal Newport. Any more thoughts on the writer's struggle? Anyone?

text:
<@U01RHT8800N> Sorry for the late reply! Meant to say, I'd love to learn about anything you find to help re: most for least approach.

As for basic prioritization, I have found using a Cause & Effect Matrix can be helpful in "force ranking" what should be done based on the inputs (i.e., list of things you COULD do) you deem most important (and which can be changed over time):

<https://sixsigmadsi.com/how-to-complete-the-ce-matrix/>

Might be worth a look?

attachments.title: How to Complete the Six Sigma Cause and Effect Matrix
attachments.text: A Cause and Effect Matrix Matrix is a tool to help the project team to Prioritize the Process Inputs. It relates Process Steps to Inputs.
attachments.fallback: Sixsigma DSI: How to Complete the Six Sigma Cause and Effect Matrix

text: My company's blog is all about community building! <https://www.higherlogic.com/blog>. I don't know if you'll find exactly what you're looking for there as it's less about marketing and more about building community among your customers. If not, maybe these articles from Grow & Convert are up your alley?  <https://growandconvert.com/content-marketing/community-content-promotion/>  <https://growandconvert.com/content-marketing/content-promotion-tactics/>

text: As a writer working with a new brand, what documents do you find most helpful to receive at the outset? brand voice, personas, audience insights...

elements.text: As a writer working with a new brand, what documents do you find most helpful to receive at the outset? brand voice, personas, audience insights...

text: all of those + product positioning and any insights on top performing content

elements.text: all of those + product positioning and any insights on top performing content

text: I recently read a book called “Futureproof” about automation, and it suggested putting a rubber band around your phone when you’re trying to reduce how much time you spend on it. It’s not a complete barrier to using it but adds friction and reminds you to get in, do what you need to do, and get out

text: I find that I never have enough audience information. So I guess personas! What's worked/hasn't in the past. what content performs really well. Definitely product positioning, too - what do we do better than competitors and what do competitors do better than us?

elements.text: I find that I never have enough audience information. So I guess personas! What's worked/hasn't in the past. what content performs really well. Definitely product positioning, too - what do we do better than competitors and what do competitors do better than us?

text: I'm curious about your expectations of writers for turnaround time on revisions. Context: I'm at a small editorial agency. We have both core folks who do a lot of work with us and writers who do regular work for us but don't tend to be working on more than a couple of pieces for us at a time. We often get client requests for next day or same-day turnaround on revisions, and writers - especially those in the second group - sometimes bristle at that. So I'm curious how much time you'd give a writer for a standard revision (eg, not a total overhaul) on, say, 1,000 words.

elements.text: I'm curious about your expectations of writers for turnaround time on revisions. Context: I'm at a small editorial agency. We have both core folks who do a lot of work with us and writers who do regular work for us but don't tend to be working on more than a couple of pieces for us at a time. We often get client requests for next day or same-day turnaround on revisions, and writers - especially those in the second group - sometimes bristle at that. So I'm curious how much time you'd give a writer for a standard revision (eg, not a total overhaul) on, say, 1,000 words.

text: I would say 2-3 business days, but often we agree on that up front and make editing SLAs part of the contract or statement of work we have together. I think same day is totally unreasonable.

elements.text: I would say 2-3 business days, but often we agree on that up front and make editing SLAs part of the contract or statement of work we have together. I think same day is totally unreasonable.

text: I agree. Our standard timeframe for revision requests is 2 business days

elements.text: I agree. Our standard timeframe for revision requests is 2 business days

text: I'm a content markteting manager going from having 0 direct reports to 2 in the next quarter (both new hires). I spoke to my boss briefly about a change in compensation and he said I'll see what I can do. Any tips on navigating this conversation or suggestions for what is an appropriate increase for this change in responsibilities?

text: <@URAV154AV> <@U01AU94TABA> Interesting. Are you at agencies or at firms doing their own content marketing?

text: In-house at companies doing their own content marketing.

elements.text: In-house at companies doing their own content marketing.

text: Are you paying them per piece or are they on retainer with you?

elements.text: Are you paying them per piece or are they on retainer with you?

text: They're paid hourly.

elements.text: They're paid hourly.

text: I'm an in house content strategist who uses freelancers. They are paid by the piece.

elements.text: I'm an in house content strategist who uses freelancers. They are paid by the piece.

text: I establish a comfy SLA, and then build in rush pricing for things that fall outside of it. Sometimes the SLA is formal, sometimes it's kinda "trained" over time.

elements.text: I establish a comfy SLA, and then build in rush pricing for things that fall outside of it. Sometimes the SLA is formal, sometimes it's kinda "trained" over time.

text:
Turnaround is such a massive "it depends." In some circumstances I can crank out 600 words in an hour. Or that assignment might need 2-3 days of noodling. A short tweet could be authored (and authored well) in a minute... or it might need a day if the brain wants to snag.

All these factors shift with both total workload and type of workload. Rarely (if ever) have I seen an editorial desk that has this balance of timing, type, and total workload optimized in any way :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Turnaround is such a massive "it depends." In some circumstances I can crank out 600 words in an hour. Or that assignment might need 2-3 days of noodling. A short tweet could be authored (and authored well) in a minute... or it might need a day if the brain wants to snag.

All these factors shift with both total workload and type of workload. Rarely (if ever) have I seen an editorial desk that has this balance of timing, type, and total workload optimized in any way

text: Yeah I’ve definitely paid rush fees to move things along faster than our initial agreement (or from the start). I think the important thing for anyone hiring freelancers to keep in mind is that unless you’re their only client, it’s not reasonable to expect same-day turnarounds because you’re potentially taking time away from that writer’s other clients and their ability to hit those deadlines. I try to be respectful of that as a client.

I try to be respectful of that as a client.
